name: Andreas Kollegger
title: Neo4j Staff
bio_excerpt: Back when Neo4j was just a single tidy Java jar, I was doing international do-gooder work. Specifically, I was helping build Zambia's national health information system. Most patient record systems are really billing systems. We wanted patient care. Struggling to stretch an RDBMS schema to be both flexible and predictable led to my personal graph e…
bio_raw:
Back when Neo4j was just a single tidy Java jar, I was doing international do-gooder work. Specifically, I was helping build Zambia's national health information system. Most patient record systems are really billing systems. We wanted patient care. Struggling to stretch an RDBMS schema to be both flexible and predictable led to my personal graph epiphany. 

My neighbor at the time (in Baltimore, MD!) happened to be building an ontology database. Close enough. "Hey Bill, could we use your database for patient records?" "Do you have a budget?" "Well, we're supposed to use all open-source." "Hmm.. go take a look at this project called 'Neo4j'".

I've grown with Neo4j from contributor, to core engineer, to developer relations, to product management. Now I'm back with developer relations, spending time with amazing people, sharing ideas and helping build graph-powered tools and applications. 

Feel like a personal chat? Book some time with me using [Calendly/akollegger](https://calendly.com/akollegger/chat-with-abk)

Or join me any Tuesday for [open office hours](https://calendar.google.com/event?action=TEMPLATE&tmeid=NTI5bDNyMm1rdGZqMnZuMDZtdmJ1OHNzM2RfMjAyMTAxMTlUMTYwMDAwWiBhbmRyZWFzLmtvbGxlZ2dlckBuZW90ZWNobm9sb2d5LmNvbQ&tmsrc=andreas.kollegger%40neotechnology.com&scp=ALL)
:hugs: ABK
bio_cooked:
Back when Neo4j was just a single tidy Java jar, I was doing international do-gooder work. Specifically, I was helping build Zambia's national health information system. Most patient record systems are really billing systems. We wanted patient care. Struggling to stretch an RDBMS schema to be both flexible and predictable led to my personal graph epiphany.

My neighbor at the time (in Baltimore, MD!) happened to be building an ontology database. Close enough. "Hey Bill, could we use your database for patient records?" "Do you have a budget?" "Well, we're supposed to use all open-source." "Hmm.. go take a look at this project called 'Neo4j'".

I've grown with Neo4j from contributor, to core engineer, to developer relations, to product management. Now I'm back with developer relations, spending time with amazing people, sharing ideas and helping build graph-powered tools and applications.

Feel like a personal chat? Book some time with me using Calendly/akollegger

Or join me any Tuesday for open office hours
ABK

name: David Allen
title: Neo4j Certified Developer
bio_raw:
Hi! My name is David, graph nerd since about 2014 or so. I originally got into working with graphs while dealing with a lot of provenance information (graphs that tell you how information was derived, from which sources).

I work at Neo4j now, in the developer relations group.

In the past back to 2014, I benefitted a lot from the Neo4j community so I'm always happy to help if I'm around.

In terms of technical background, I'm into java, javascript, python, scala on the programming side, and anything cloud related. When I have spare technical time, I like to play with aleatoric music.

groups.name: Neo4jCertified
groups.title: Neo4j Certified Developer
groups.bio_raw:
This group is exclusive to Neo4j Certified Professionals.

Links for the hands-on, advanced, training sessions, offered exclusively to our Neo4j Certified Professionals, can be found in the private [Certified Professionals category](https://discourse.neo4j.com/c/certified-professionals).  Only approved members of this group are able to access that category.

Not certified yet? 
Become [Neo4j Certified](https://neo4j.com/graphacademy/neo4j-certification/)!

groups.membership_request_template:
Please use this space to provide us with your Neo4j Certification Number. 
(you can find it directly on your Certificate or in the email you received when you passed. 

If you do not include one, your membership request to this group will not be granted. 

My Neo4j Certificate Number is:
